Artificial intelligence has gotten so good at mimicking human cognition that it can be jarring when it doesn’t quite work.
... When autofill presents the wrong words in a text. When Spotify pulls up a dud of a song Sometimes AI gets it very wrong.
But why do those glitches happen? And how are machines getting better and better at doing what our brains do?
To understand how AI works, you have to understand how human cognition works and recognize all of the processes we take for granted.
We don't think of the brain as mechanical. But cognition that seems to happen in an instant is actually a series of steps. That’s a lot like how an algorithm works.
In this interactive, we're slowing down the cognitive process to show you, step by step, how our brains work.

btn.text: How facial recognition knows who you are
How Spotify builds the perfect playlist
How autofill reads your mind when you text or email[a]

text.value: Almost half of your brain is devoted to the visual system — and a surprising amount of brainpower is used to identify faces. Facial recognition programs — now used for everything from law enforcement to unlocking phones — try to recreate that lightning-fast human cognition. It’s a work in progress.

In a fifth of a second, your brain can decide whether a photo shows a face or some other object. Some neurons in the visual cortex — aptly called “face cells” — are dedicated solely to faces. They register different features and the spatial relationship between them.

btn.text: What we see in a face

text.value: Usually you can recognize a face in fractions of a second. Take away a feature and the task is much harder. That’s because, to your brain, a face is not a single object, but a combination of features. The most important landmarks seem to be the eyes, mouth, and — surprisingly — eyebrows.
Can you recognize this face without eyebrows?
Here’s the same person’s face, but with no features removed.
Now can you guess who this is?

Most objects are harder to recognize upside-down, but faces are especially difficult. Because those landmarks are not where your face cells expect them to be, your brain has to draw on other parts of the visual cortex. You eventually get it, but the process takes longer.
Can you guess who is this?
Here’s the same person’s face, but oriented the way humans are used to seeing it.
Now can you guess who this is?

AI has the same problem humans do — but worse. Shown an upside-down photo of Tom Cruise, a machine draws a blank. An upside-down photo of Kim Kardashian confuses AI so much, it thinks it’s looking at Ozzy Osbourne — likely because the system was never trained on upside-down portraits and can’t generalize.

Facial recognition software is trained to recognize features and the distance between them. Often, it’s better than humans: People can recognize about 5,000 faces, while AI can learn millions and identify them in moments. But while the human brain can work around a missing feature, AI often can’t. When it sees Kim Kardashian without eyebrows, AI is only about 35 percent sure it's her.

visual.title: AI and racial profiling of faces
visual.caption: Members of Congress misidentified by Amazon’s Rekognition software (clockwise from top left): Rep. John Lewis, Rep. Luis V. Gutiérrez, Rep. Bobby Rush, Sen. Edward J. Markey.

text.value: But AI is only as good as its training — and some of its errors have damaging consequences. AI software has been shown to make more mistakes identifying dark-skinned people, especially women, since some algorithms have been trained largely on photos of white men. The ACLU found that Amazon’s face recognition software falsely matched photos of 28 members of Congress with mug shots. 11 of those false matches -- almost 40% -- were non-white representatives, while Americans of color make up only 20% of Congress. Because of kinks in the technology and social biases built into the datasets, many activists don’t think facial recognition is ready for widespread use.

btn.text: How face recognition is being used

visual.title: You’ve been spotted
visual.caption: A demonstration of NEC's video face recognition technology.

text.value: Cities around the country are passing laws to protect privacy and regulate how agencies, including police, can use face recognition software. Still, many stadiums and airports are rolling out the technology, arguing it will keep people safe and help lines move faster.

It could be that humans and AI do best when they work together. A few years ago, the London police department created a team of “super-recognizers:” people with a mysterious talent for recognizing thousands of faces, often after one glimpse or years later. In 2016, the group made about 2,500 positive identifications in criminal cases. One study found that pairing a super recognizer with AI gets better results than humans or technology alone.[b][c][d] These findings suggest humans and AI approach face recognition a little differently, with separate strengths and weaknesses that can be combined for powerful abilities.

btn.text: Discover more about AI and the brain

text.value: When you listen to someone speak, your brain makes educated guesses about what’s coming next. Artificial intelligence uses a similar process to predict what words you’ll text next on your phone.

speech.title: This word could save your life

text.value: For early humans to adapt and survive, their brains had to establish the relationships between speech and sensory events. Correctly guessing what comes next could save precious seconds in life-or-death situations. To do that, specific neurons in the auditory cortex respond to different phonemes, the smallest units of sound that distinguish one word from another. In English, there are 44 phonemes, such as “w” and “f” and “t.”
It’s hard to pick the “right” word without context.
Those groups of neurons learn the relationships between different sounds, and the possibility that they go together, to predict what might come next.
What word comes next?

To predict text, AI also tries to  understand the relationships between words. Whether it’s the messaging app on an iPhone or Gmail’s new Smart Compose feature, these AIs try to predict the next word you’ll type by learning the correlations among letters, words, and sentences — through training on millions of documents.

Presented with this phrase, iPhone AI suggests what the next word in the sequence will be, offering three possible choices. Every iPhone user will get different suggestions, learned from the language patterns found in that person’s message history.
Can you guess which three words AI suggested for one user?

btn.text: Next: When AI gets it wrong

speech.title: How AI learns the worst from us

text.value: When AI trains on old documents, it learns human biases. Google Translate used to turn the Turkish phrase “O bir doktor” into “He is a doctor,” though “o” is a gender-neutral third-person pronoun. Why? The algorithm had seen  more examples of doctors identified as men. Humans corrected the problem, and Google now offers up both a “he” and “she” translation.
But AI can also help humans function better. People with dyslexia, who struggle to read at speed and predict the words that  come next, can use AI-assisted tools to fix spelling errors.

A cutting-edge language model, GPT-2, can write full paragraphs and stories after getting a short prompt. Some of the text it creates can be a little wonky, but plenty of it reads like a person wrote it. It's convincing enough that its creators aren’t releasing all the details behind the technology, because of concerns that it could be used to automate trolling or fake news creation. For the time being, those are still the realm of human writers.[e][f][g][h]

text.value: From lullabies to wedding hymns to funeral dirges, music is bound up with emotion. But what makes a song feel right for a moment or mood? Your brain learns, over time, how to pick the perfect song based on past  responses and preferences[i][j]. Spotify and other AI-driven music services start with similar methods but add a whole lot more to build customized playlists.

Your brain is hard-wired to make sense of music. Parts of the auditory cortex responds selectively[k][l] to music-like sounds, but not to speech or non-musical noises. Other regions of the brain, such as xx and xx, tmight also be involved in music processing.

music.title: Are my sad songs sadder than yours?

text.value: Some perceptions of music are cultural, but some are universal. In one study, researchers asked members of the Mafa, a Cameroon tribe with no exposure to Western culture, to listen to pop songs. Most of the Mafa correctly labeled the songs happy, sad, or fearful, even without understanding the words..

music.title: If you’re happy and you know it...

text.value: Drag the slider to show where this music falls on a scale from happiest to saddest.

You might innately sense that a song is happy, but AI has to be taught. Machines measure mood  with a metric called “valence” — the higher the valence, the happier the song. Spotify hires music experts to train its AI on valence of some songs, then applies that algorithm to other songs on the platform. The rules are secret, but we know they’re fine-tuned regularly.
Here’s how your answers compared to Spotify’s valence measurements.

music.title: An AI playlist just for you

text.value: To put together a personalized Discover Weekly playlist, Spotify’s AI takes into consideration different pieces of information. The software compares music you’ve listened to with songs you might not have heard (with some extra rules they hard code, like no Christmas music after December 25). It also looks at a piece of music’s valence, time signature, key, tempo, and “danceability — a metric based on tempo, rhythm stability, beat strength, and overall regularity.
Where does this music fall on a scale from least to most danceable?
Here’s how your answers compared to Spotify’s valence measurements.

Another Spotify metric compares your listening history to that of other users. If you and a friend have similar tastes, perhaps you’ll like her favorite new song. Another final tool trawls the internet for text about the song innews articles and blogs. A non-algorithmic consideration? Playlists put together by everyone from casual listeners to professionals hired by Spotify.
Why AI sometimes gets it wrong

music.title: The right data, the wrong song

text.value: Even with all this data, the Spotify recommendation engine sometimes offers you a song you hate. That’s because Spotify focuses on  technical elements, but doesn’t know the context — a break-up, a bad memory, the unpredictability of taste. [m][n]

Music leaves an impression on the brain. [o][p]According to recent research, the part of the brain that responds to music remains active in patients with Alzheimer’s. Music that was meaningful to a person can even pull him or her out of the haze for a short while. Music moves us through time, bringing memories into vivid relief.

The most popular Spotify playlist, RapCaviar, owes it popularity to a handful of people putting the 50 or so songs together every week. Almost twelve million people follow the playlist, which is responsible for launching the career of artists and helping singles get millions of streams. The handpicked songs helps surface new songs to listeners, which in turn influence personalized playlists like Discover Weekly. Tastemakers still inform the algorithms and not the other way around.
